reviews.review_msg: Be ready to take notes and study them carefully. If you like lecture formats, this is the professor for you. Class is enjoyable but can get quite tedious. If you have a short attention span it will be difficult to get through lectures. Overall, a very knowledgeable prof who provides good feedback. You will learn a lot from him.

He is the best. Very focused on primary sources and leaves lots of room for students to analyze the text. Really knows his stuff, but will pose the right questions and wait, instead of talking at you. I find his method of teaching to be one of the most effective I've encountered. Somewhat mysterious but always has a twinkle in his eye.

Craig is a good professor, and a smart guy. Don't get me wrong, the texts and documentaries he provided were interesting. There is just a lot. And I mean, a lot! There is no lecture, but still, I feel as if there wasn't much care given to just how much was being demanded of student's time here.

Doesn't actually lecture. VERY reading intensive (~300 pages/week). Makes you watch 3 hours worth of video content because he enjoys watching movies (so apparently you have to as well). Doesn't even really answer emails on time.

Take this class if you have nothing else to do with your time.

I would like to preface this by saying I definitely did not give this professor a fair shake. However very early he dropped a assignment. I cant go into the full story because of word limit, but it was a poorly executed assignment which I interpreted as a red flag. Some questions you just could not answer because of their nature.

No lecture videos, no lectures but 2-3 videos (1 hour long each) and 150-200 pages of readings per week. PER WEEK. It definitely felt like I paid $1,000 to be stressed out and watch movies and read. Tests are based on the nitty-gritty details. I still don't know what John looks like or sounds like. Don't take it unless you HAVE to.

As a history enthusiast, I loved this class!  Keeping up with readings and lectures is really important.  If you regularly participate, you'll get lots of feedback from the prof and she will provide help if you reach out.  I appreciated that she often allowed me to explore/focus on niche topics that I was interested in related to course content.

An outrageous sorry of an excuse for an incompetent instructor whose only redeemable qualities other than harshly berating students with a consistent barrage of unhelpful criticism and back-handed comments in a condescending and tactless manner. Fails to offer any modicum of constructive feedback while also having an uninspiring presentation style

She is the only professor who thinks the grammar matters in the paper. Also, somehow I think her lecture has bias on the certain area of history. Although she claimed that the lecture of the Second World War would be focusing on the entire world. She did not give a lot of information and lecture time to Asia and North Africa battles.
Well respected in her field. She is totally approachable and takes the time to help students who ask for it. One of the best History Dept profs at SFU!
Critical feedback in written assignments, but is very helpful. She knows her stuff very well.
Had Dr. Rossi for WW2 online and maybe the best put together online class I have taken at SFU.

Wow, I cannot believe how rude she is with her comments and feedback on assignments. I made one very slight and minor mistake, and she ripped into me on her comments, which was shocking. It seems like from the other comments on here, that people said her feedback is rude and very blunt. I am surprised with her rudeness on comments. Very strange.
Extremely difficult course and does not give good lectures. On top of that a very hard marker.

Honestly I don't know how she is a professor at SFU. Contradicts her own lecture content when mentioning her content in essays, etc., Sometimes her comments can be borderline rude towards students. Only take this course if you're passionate about the subject.

Gives you so much reading per week, you'd think it was for two courses. You may be able to skip parts of each week and kind of gamble on the readings to stay relevant during class discussions but lecture slides are a must to listen to at least.
Super nice, readings are interesting but heavy.
She is very picky about grammar, she is not helpful when it comes to explaining things when asking for help. Sometimes her grades, do not match with people's expectations.

Shes disorganized, doesnt have clear grading rubrics, takes forever to mark, and doesnt give good feedback. Her class was partially online so she had recorded powerpoints but the audio doesnt match the notes... For the in class tutorials, she doesnt talk about her lectures and expects us to know stuff that wasnt even taught for the quizzes.

Lauren is a great, knowledgable prof. The class is very heavy in its readings, which you need to do to participate in the tutorials. If you don't like reading, don't take this class. Grading is fair, but you definitely need to put a lot of effort in to get a good mark. That being said, I highly recommend this class and prof as you learn so much!

So. much. reading. So. many. assignments. I took this course online and the recorded lecture were monotone, stiffly read from a script and boring, despite the fact that the content is really interesting on its own. 3-4 weekly discussion posts required + assignments on a regularly basis. No exam BUT honestly way too much work for what it's worth
Great prof, incredibly knowledgeable, so make sure you know your stuff for tutorial

Luke Clossey is a GREAT professor. His quizzes are a little obscure but it only ensures that you know the material well. He quizzes on time periods, people/places/terminology, as well as gives essays. These things ensure that you have a comprehensive knowledge of the material. Don't take him if you are looking to coast through a class. Enjoyable.
